newsitem.title: USA: Indiana corn, soybean emergence remains slow.
newsitem.headline: Indiana corn, soybean emergence remains slow.

text.p: Emergence of both corn and soybeans in Indiana remained slow in the week to Sunday due to below normal temperatures and a lack of sunshine, according to the Indiana Agricultural Statistics Service.

"Some areas received heavy rainfall resulting in ponding and flooding in low lying areas of fields. Farmers have already replanted some fields and more replanting will be necessary in drowned out areas," the report noted.
Corn planting was 98 percent complete, up from 97 percent a week earlier, while soybeans were 87 percent planted versus last week's 81 percent.
Both crops were ahead of their respective five-year average pace of 83 and 62 percent.
Corn was rated six percent excellent, 48 percent good, 39 percent fair, six percent poor and one percent very poor.
Winter wheat was rated 70 percent good to excellent, down from 71 percent a week earlier.
"The rains that caused problems for the Indy 500 may also bode ill for some of Indiana's wheat crop," the report said.
"Wheat that was flowering during rainy periods may become infected by the scab fungus," it noted.
